question: The mechanism of direct transfer of free DNA involves _____
exp: Transformation is a process of the transfer of DNA itself from one bacterium to another. This may occur either in nature or in a laboratory. DNA is released from a bacterium by lysis, which may be taken up by recipient bacterium that must be competent. In laboratory conditions, DNA may be extracted from one type of bacterium and introduced into genetically different bacteria. The cell walls of bacteria in vitro are made more permeable for DNA uptake by using substances, such as calcium chloride. Transduction is the process by which foreign DNA is introduced into a cell by a virus or viral vector. Conjugationis the process by which onebacteriumtransfers genetic material to another through direct contact. This takes place through a pilus. During conjugation, onebacteriumserves as the donor of the genetic material, and the other serves as the recipient.
topic_name: General Microbiology Pa 1 (History, Microscopy, Stains and Structure and Physiology of Bacteria)

question: In a bacterial growth curve, the period in which maximum cell size is obtained is_____
exp: Bacterial Growth Curve: The bacterial growth curve shows the following four distinct phases - 1) Lag phase: Bacteria adapt to their new environment. Enzymes and intermediates are formed and accumulate until they are present in concentrations that permit growth to resume. Bacterial cell size is maximum in end of the lag phase. It is Preparatory phase Accumulation of enzymes and metabolites 2. Log or Exponential Phase: 3. Stationary phase: The bacterial growth almost stops completely due to lack of essential nutrients, lack of water oxygen, change in pH of the medium, etc. and accumulation of their own toxic metabolic wastes. Death rate of bacteria equals the rate of replication of bacteria. Endospores sta forming during this stage. Many bacteria sta producing exotoxins. Bacteria become Gram variable and show irregular staining. 4. Decline phase: During this phase, the bacterial population declines due to death of cells. The decline phase stas due to - Accumulation of toxic products and autolytic enzymes and Exhaustion of nutrients. Involution forms are common in this stage.

question: Agent which on addition to a colony inhibits its growth and on removal the colony regrow is
exp: Option 1 A bacteriostatic agent or bacteriostat -biological or chemical agent that stops bacteria from reproducing, while not necessarily killing them otherwise. "Bacteriostatic" means that the agent prevents the growth of bacteria (i. e., it keeps them in the stationary phase of growth), and "bactericidal" means that it kills bacteria. Option 2 Bactericidal: propey by which a biocide is able to kill bacteria. Bactericidal action differs from bacteriostasis only in being irreversible (ie, the "killed" organism can no longer reproduce even after being removed from contact with the agent). Option 3 Antibiotic: A substance that interferes with a paicular step of cellular metabolism; may be either bactericidal or bacteriostatic Option 4 Antiseptic: An agent that destroys or inhibits the growth of microorganisms in or on living tissue or biologic fluids
topic_name: General Microbiology Pa 1 (History, Microscopy, Stains and Structure and Physiology of Bacteria)

question: Which one of the following statements about cilia is true?
exp: Both flagella and cilia have a 9 + 2 arrangement of microtubules. This arrangement refers to the 9 fused pairs of microtubules on the outside of a cylinder, and the 2 unfused microtubules in the center Cilia contain an axoneme with ciliary dynein arms extending unidirectionally from one member of each doublet. Dynein "arms" attached to the microtubules serve as the molecular motors. Ciliary dynein has ATPase activity, and when it splits ATP, the adjacent doublets slide past one another and the cilium moves.

opb: They do not contain an axoneme.
opd: They are nearly identical to centrioles.

question: Lysis of bacterial colony in culture is seen by which -
exp: Bacteriophage: A bacteriophage is a type of virus that infects bacteria. Word "bacteriophage" means "bacteria eater, " because bacteriophages destroy their host cells.. Lytic phages can kill the bacteria hence causing lysis in culture medium This propey can also be used in treatment of bacterial infection, such as post-burn and wound infections. (Phage therapy)

question: All the following pathogenic bacteria fulfill Kochs postulates except
exp: Koch's postulates: A microorganism was accepted as the causative agent of infectious disease, only when it satisfied all the following criteria: 1. The microorganism must be present in every case of the disease but absent from healthy host. 2. The suspected microorganism must be isolated and grown in a pure culture from lesions of the disease. 3. The isolated organism, in pure culture, when inoculated in suitable laboratory animals should produce a similar disease. 4. The same microorganism must be isolated again in pure culture from the lesions produced in experimental animals. Most of the human bacterial pathogens satisfy Koch's postulates except for Mycobacterium leprae (leprosy) Treponema pallidum (syphilis) Both these bacteria are yet to be grown in cell-free culture media.
topic_name: General Microbiology Pa 1 (History, Microscopy, Stains and Structure and Physiology of Bacteria)

question: Swarming growth on culture is characteristic of which Gram-negative organism
exp: 1. Swarming - Proteus has an ability to swarm (or spread) on solid media. They spread on the surface of the plate in successive waves to form a thin filmy layer in concentric circles. This is known as swarming. 2. Organism which swarm: Proteus, Clostridium tetani, V. parahemolyticus, and Serratia. Clostridium welchii - non motile Clostridium tetani - Gram positive Bacillus cereus- motile, gram positive rod Proteus mirabilis - peritrichous flagella

question: Robe Koch assistant advised him to use agar instead of gelatin for solidifying culture media for cultivation of bacteria because
exp: Gelatin was the substance originally used to gel culture media. However, gelatin is liquid at 35oC., the optimum temperature for many bacteria. In addition, some bacteria are capable of liquifying the gelatin, making it an unsuitable solidifying agent. Agar has neither of these drawbacks. Agar is preferred over gelatin, as it is bacteriologically ine, melts at 98degC and usually solidifies at 42degC.
